document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the genus Harmothoe Kinberg, 1856 (Polychaeta: Polynoidae) in the Northeast Atlantic

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the genus Harmothoe Kinberg, 1856 (Polychaeta: Polynoidae) in the Northeast Atlantic

heading.emphasis:
Key to the Northeast Atlantic species of
Harmothoe
,
Acanthicolepis
and
Leucia

subSubSection.paragraph: This identification key is supplemented by Figs. 1–5 which illustrate the main diagnostic characters of the species: (1) presence/absence of eyes, and if present the position of the anterior pair of eyes; (2) elytral characters, i.e. shape and distribution of micro- and macrotubercles and papillae; (3) length and shape of the neuropodial supra-acicular process; (4) chaetal characters (Note: for further diagnostic characters please refer to the respective species description).

paragraph.keyLead: - With eyes (eye pigment might be faded, but silhouette still visible) .......................................................................... 3

2. Elytra without macrotubercles; microtubercles elongate conical .................................
Harmothoe anoculata
( Fig. 1 )

- Elytra with drop-shaped or cylindrical macrotubercles near posterior margin; microtubercles conical or spine-shaped or cylindrical with bi- or multifid tip .............................................................
Harmothoe ingolfiana
( Figs. 1 ; 24B,C )

4. Elytral surface with polygonal fields; tubercles conical in anterior part, becoming flattened thorn-shaped towards posterior margin, large and small thorns alternating.............................................
Harmothoe areolata
( Fig. 1 ; 9B,C )

5. Elytral margin without papillae (except for very short ones on anteriormost elytra), surface covered by scattered, low, conical microtubercles ................................................................................
Harmothoe spinifera
( Fig. 1 ; 31B,C )

6. Elytral margin with long fringing papillae; surface covered by cylindrical microtubercles with bifid to crown-like multifid tip and few scattered papillae; anterior elytra with or without conical to club-shaped macrotubercles near posterior margin ..................................................................................................
Harmothoe antilopes
( Fig. 1 ; 8B, C )
8. Elytral margin without papillae (occasionally few, scattered in anteriormost elytra present) .................................... 9

9. Anterior half of elytra with numerous conical microtubercles; posterior half with rather indistinct, scattered, soft conical to mamilliform macrotubercles (16 pairs of elytra!) .................................................
Leucia violacea
( Fig. 2 )

- Elytral surface covered by conical microtubercles; conical macrotubercles scattered on surface and near posterior margin ......................................................................................................
Harmothoe fraserthomsoni
( Fig. 2 ; 18B,C )

11. Macrotubercles spiny distally, in a row near posterior margin, microtubercles globose, bifid to branched multifid, larger towards posterior margin (16 pairs of elytra!) .................................................................
Leucia nivea
( Fig. 2 )

12. Macrotubercles as strong spines near posterior margin; microtubercles covering surface, with simple, bifid, or multifid tip, becoming gradually larger towards posterior margin (18 pairs of elytra!)
Acanthicolepis asperrima
( Fig. 2 )

- Macrotubercles slender thorn-shaped in a row near posterior margin ..................
Harmothoe serrata
( Fig. 2 ; 30B,C )

14. Elytral tubercles often grouped on mounds, others isolated, giving elytron reticulate appearance (visible on clean elytra!) ..................................................................................................................
Harmothoe impar
( Figs. 3 ; 23B,C )

16. Macrotubercles prominent, stick-shaped in a row near posterior margin and some scattered more centrally .............. ..........................................................................................................................
Harmothoe rarispina
( Figs. 3 ; 29B,C )

18. Macrotubercles rounded, soft and flattened in a row near posterior margin, giving margin a scallop-shaped appearence .............................................................................................................
Harmothoe fragilis
( Fig. 3 ; 17B,C )

19. Macrotubercles conical, blunt, in a dense row near posterior margin; macrotubercles rather small, but still distinctly larger than largest microtubercles ....................................................................
Harmothoe vesiculosa
( Fig. 3 ; 32B,C )
- Macrotubercles conical to globose scattered near posterior margin ......................................................................... 20

20. Elytral margin with short scattered papillae; neurochaetae fragile, smooth or with reduced rows of spines, tips unidentate or minutely bidentate ......................................................................
Harmothoe abyssicola
( Figs. 3 ; 6B,C )

- Elytra with long papillae at outer lateral margin, becoming shorter towards posterior margin; neurochaetae stout with distinct rows of spines and bi- and unidentate tips .....................
Harmothoe mariannae
n. sp.
( Figs. 3 ; 26B,C )

21. Microtubercles flattened, irregular, consisting of an elevated broad rim surrounding a depressed central area ........... ...............................................................................................................................
Harmothoe pokoui
( Fig. 4 ; 28B,C )

23. Elytral margin with long papillae; tip of neurochaetae falcate (hooked) .............
Harmothoe bellani
( Fig. 4 ; 11B,C )

- Elytral margin with scattered, short papillae; tip of neurochaetae rather straight ...
Harmothoe evei
( Figs. 4 ; 14B,C )
24. Elytral margin without papillae; microtubercles in a patch near anterior margin .................................................... 25
- Elytral margin distinctly papillate; microtubercles arranged otherwise ........................................................................ 26

25. Noto- and neurochaetae with faint rows of spines; tip of neurochaetae distinctly falcate (hooked). Neuropodial supra-acicular process thick, stout ...........................................................
Harmothoe benthaliana
( Figs. 4 ; 12B,C,E )

- Noto- and neurochaetae with distinct rows of spines; tip of neurochaetae straight or only slightly falcate. Neuropodial supra-acicular process slender, digitiform ................................................
Harmothoe longisetis
( Fig. 4 ; 25B–D )

27. Microtubercles conical, covering surface, getting larger towards posterior margin. Neurochaetae very slender and, except for some uppermost neurochaetae, with reduced rows of spines ....................................................................... ...........................................................................................................
Harmothoe fernandi
n. sp.
( Figs. 5 ; 16B,C,F–I )

- Microtubercles conical, in a patch near anterior margin. Neurochaetae stout, with distinct rows of spines ................. ........................................................................................................................
Harmothoe oculinarum
( Fig. 5 ; 27B,C )

29. Microtubercles conical in anterior part, becoming gradually larger and club-shaped towards posterior margin; papillae more or less evenly distributed at outer lateral and posterior margin ..........
Harmothoe gilchristi
( Fig. 5 ; 19B,C )

- Microtubercles relatively large, rounded to conical with blunt tip; papillae numerous at outer lateral margin, scattered at posterior margin ..................................................................................
Harmothoe aequespina
( Fig. 5 ; 7B,C )

30. Microtubercles mainly present in anterior half of elytron, posterior half covered by papillae and some scattered microtubercles. Neuropodia with remarkably long, digitiform supra-acicular process ................................................. .............................................................................................................................
Harmothoe glabra
( Figs. 5 ; 20B–D )
